- 3-
Bill Cowden,
PAA#1 and George Sellett met us at the airport and escorted us
to the Intercontinental Mandarin, a 600 room 20 story hotel on Victoria
island about two blacks from the
Post Office just behind the ferry landing.
Our room looks out on the harbor with its constantly changing seene of
ferry boats, there are 8 crossing as I write this line, hundreds of
junks
freighters, from all
over the world with a few war ships and a passenger
liner or
two.
Most of the treighters never touch shore, they are unloaded
and loaded by a swarm of small craft coming along side and leaving all day
and all night.
Wed. Dec. 9th.
tended to tickets changing money etc. in the morning.
George Sellett came
by for us about one o'clock and we drove to his house for
lunch.
We crossed to the mainland
by auto ferry and then out Nathan road
by the old Peninsula Hotel and between apartment buildings, mostly new, to
the mountains that nark the beginning of the "leased territory".
We climbed
up and up along a perfect road to the Carleton Hotel and just beyond that is
George's new "estate".
We drove through a gate to find ourselves in a small
garden full of those wonderful chrysanthemuns such as only Chinese gardeners
can groW.
The ground floor of the stone house is taken up with a screen
which partly hides a rumpus room which the former owner had for the
children.
A winding stairway leads to an upper floor with bedrooms, 3, each
with bath to the right and to the left a larger living room with roan high
sliging glass doors which open on a wide terrace which overlooks the whole
of Hong Kong•
Fron the terrace the land falls away steeply to another
terrace and
then another 20 feet down to a second with
a small swimming
pool
and then yet another terrace which is his
truck garden.
It is a real
gem.
The gouse is full of beautiful Chinese furniture.
George has a chauffeur
cook, gardener, coolie and wash anah, quite an establishment and not the
least
of the attractions.
We did
not
get hone
until late so had an early
snack (after George's enormous steak lunch) and to bed early. My cold is
better.
Thurs.
Dec. 10t%h
Shopping•
One interesting government development in
Kowloon was the
reclaiming of a large tract of
tidal
shallowa where a complex
of apartments surrounds a harbor and provides a perfect shelter for junks
and small boats during typhoons or rough
weather.
We have fairly definite plans (for us) now.
We leave here at 1 p.I. on
Dec. 16 for Manila and leave there on the 20th for Honolulu arriving the
same day (thanks to gaining a day
crossing the International Date
Line).
You will no doubt wonder about the Chinese Communists,
and so do we.
Outwardly they and China might as well be five thousand miles away.
The
bee hive which is Hong Kong does on as though everyone expected to be here
forever.
The government has just finished a 1,000 bed hospital, a
mountain is being truncated
thousands
of men work around the clock on new buildings, in factories and on docks.
The first
time I was here after the
Communist
take-over in China the
Communist flag was everywhere.
The next time about five years later I saw
a few and this time none.
Real Estate prices in the heart of Kowloon
or
Victoria (HongKong) are higher
than New York, sonething like 500 U.S. dollars
per square foot.
Friday Dec.
We had a trip by car all around
this island with coffee
at the Repulse Bay Hotel where we lived for a while.
Then we had lunch
at the Pei ing restaurant with C.H. (Fatty)Moo.
Others
there were Nr. and
ost 1 on soneR at Canton:
George Sellett and my old friend Nixon, former
We had all of
our old favorites, Pekin
duck, sharks fin soup, mandarin fish, chicken and walnuts, bahboo shoots,
